Start simple, but think scalable.Today I was tweaking a basic API view, and it hit me how DRF makes even complex things feel manageableâ€”like handling nested serializers, authentication, or pagination.But hereâ€™s the catch:Itâ€™s easy to fall into the trap of overengineering early on.Start with APIView, understand Serializer deeply, and THEN move to ViewSets and routers.Master the basics â†’ Build smart â†’ Scale clean.Every endpoint you design is part of a bigger conversation between systems. But last week, while redesigning a branch topology using FortiGate, I was reminded just how powerful and relevant OSPF still is.Hereâ€™s what happened:We had a multi-branch setup with dynamic routing needs, redundancy requirements, and a mandate to minimize manual configs. FortiGateâ€™s capabilities made the security part easyâ€”but OSPF stepped in to do the heavy lifting on routing.A few key takeaways:OSPFâ€™s link-state database gave us deep visibility into route changes.FortiGateâ€™s dynamic routing support is more robust than many give it credit for.Tuning OSPF cost and timers within FortiOS CLI still gives you precise control when needed.This isnâ€™t a debate between old vs. newâ€”itâ€™s about knowing what tool to use when.Curious to hear from others: Are you still leveraging OSPF with FortiGate? But last week, while redesigning a branch topology using FortiGate, I was reminded just how powerful and relevant OSPF still is.Hereâ€™s what happened:We had a multi-branch setup with dynamic routing needs, redundancy requirements, and a mandate to minimize manual configs. FortiGateâ€™s capabilities made the security part easyâ€”but OSPF stepped in to do the heavy lifting on routing.A few key takeaways:OSPFâ€™s link-state database gave us deep visibility into route changes.FortiGateâ€™s dynamic routing support is more robust than many give it credit for.Tuning OSPF cost and timers within FortiOS CLI still gives you precise control when needed.This isnâ€™t a debate between old vs. newâ€”itâ€™s about knowing what tool to use when.Curious to hear from others: Are you still leveraging OSPF with FortiGate? CAN A DOMESTIC AGREEMENT BE ENFORCED?In the law of contract, There exist a presumption that social and domestic agreements are not enforceable, in other words they are not binding. The reason for this is that, it is presumed that there are no intentions to create legal relations when engaging in social and domestic agreements due to the nature of the agreements.This presumption is a rebuttable one. This means that there are instances where the court may infer an intention to create legal relations and enforce a domestic agreement.These instances may be regarded as the exceptions to the general presumption. These instances when proved or established, negates the presumption that social and domestic agreements are not binding.These instances are;When the parties within the domestic relationship were clearly not living in amity as at the time the agreement was made. This includes a situation where a couple are living apart as a result of a breakdown in the marriage. See the case of MERRITT V MERRITT.Again, a domestic agreement may be enforceable in situations were a party has made a great sacrifice in the process of making the agreement that it would be unfair and lead to great injustice if the agreement is not enforceable. In this instance, the great sacrifice represents consideration. See the case of PARKER V CLARK.Finally, a domestic agreement may be enforced by a court of law where evidence is adduced to show that parties to the contract  did intend to create legal relations in the terms of the agreement. This is because parties are free to agree to whatever they want to, so far it is within the ambit of the law.

Just a little honest chit chat with a good friend, hope you like it, give me your feedback :)

CAN A DOMESTIC AGREEMENT BE ENFORCED?In the law of contract, There exist a presumption that social and domestic agreements are not enforceable, in other words they are not binding. The reason for this is that, it is presumed that there are no intentions to create legal relations when engaging in social and domestic agreements due to the nature of the agreements.This presumption is a rebuttable one. This means that there are instances where the court may infer an intention to create legal relations and enforce a domestic agreement.These instances may be regarded as the exceptions to the general presumption. These instances when proved or established, negates the presumption that social and domestic agreements are not binding.These instances are;When the parties within the domestic relationship were clearly not living in amity as at the time the agreement was made. This includes a situation where a couple are living apart as a result of a breakdown in the marriage. See the case of MERRITT V MERRITT.Again, a domestic agreement may be enforceable in situations were a party has made a great sacrifice in the process of making the agreement that it would be unfair and lead to great injustice if the agreement is not enforceable. In this instance, the great sacrifice represents consideration. See the case of PARKER V CLARK.Finally, a domestic agreement may be enforced by a court of law where evidence is adduced to show that parties to the contract  did intend to create legal relations in the terms of the agreement. This is because parties are free to agree to whatever they want to, so far it is within the ambit of the law.

CAN A DOMESTIC AGREEMENT BE ENFORCED?In the law of contract, There exist a presumption that social and domestic agreements are not enforceable, in other words they are not binding. The reason for this is that, it is presumed that there are no intentions to create legal relations when engaging in social and domestic agreements due to the nature of the agreements.This presumption is a rebuttable one. This means that there are instances where the court may infer an intention to create legal relations and enforce a domestic agreement.These instances may be regarded as the exceptions to the general presumption. These instances when proved or established, negates the presumption that social and domestic agreements are not binding.These instances are;When the parties within the domestic relationship were clearly not living in amity as at the time the agreement was made. This includes a situation where a couple are living apart as a result of a breakdown in the marriage. See the case of MERRITT V MERRITT.Again, a domestic agreement may be enforceable in situations were a party has made a great sacrifice in the process of making the agreement that it would be unfair and lead to great injustice if the agreement is not enforceable. In this instance, the great sacrifice represents consideration. See the case of PARKER V CLARK.Finally, a domestic agreement may be enforced by a court of law where evidence is adduced to show that parties to the contract  did intend to create legal relations in the terms of the agreement. This is because parties are free to agree to whatever they want to, so far it is within the ambit of the law.

CAN A DOMESTIC AGREEMENT BE ENFORCED?In the law of contract, There exist a presumption that social and domestic agreements are not enforceable, in other words they are not binding. The reason for this is that, it is presumed that there are no intentions to create legal relations when engaging in social and domestic agreements due to the nature of the agreements.This presumption is a rebuttable one. This means that there are instances where the court may infer an intention to create legal relations and enforce a domestic agreement.These instances may be regarded as the exceptions to the general presumption. These instances when proved or established, negates the presumption that social and domestic agreements are not binding.These instances are;When the parties within the domestic relationship were clearly not living in amity as at the time the agreement was made. This includes a situation where a couple are living apart as a result of a breakdown in the marriage. See the case of MERRITT V MERRITT.Again, a domestic agreement may be enforceable in situations were a party has made a great sacrifice in the process of making the agreement that it would be unfair and lead to great injustice if the agreement is not enforceable. In this instance, the great sacrifice represents consideration. See the case of PARKER V CLARK.Finally, a domestic agreement may be enforced by a court of law where evidence is adduced to show that parties to the contract  did intend to create legal relations in the terms of the agreement. This is because parties are free to agree to whatever they want to, so far it is within the ambit of the law.

CAN A DOMESTIC AGREEMENT BE ENFORCED?In the law of contract, There exist a presumption that social and domestic agreements are not enforceable, in other words they are not binding. The reason for this is that, it is presumed that there are no intentions to create legal relations when engaging in social and domestic agreements due to the nature of the agreements.This presumption is a rebuttable one. This means that there are instances where the court may infer an intention to create legal relations and enforce a domestic agreement.These instances may be regarded as the exceptions to the general presumption. These instances when proved or established, negates the presumption that social and domestic agreements are not binding.These instances are;When the parties within the domestic relationship were clearly not living in amity as at the time the agreement was made. This includes a situation where a couple are living apart as a result of a breakdown in the marriage. See the case of MERRITT V MERRITT.Again, a domestic agreement may be enforceable in situations were a party has made a great sacrifice in the process of making the agreement that it would be unfair and lead to great injustice if the agreement is not enforceable. In this instance, the great sacrifice represents consideration. See the case of PARKER V CLARK.Finally, a domestic agreement may be enforced by a court of law where evidence is adduced to show that parties to the contract  did intend to create legal relations in the terms of the agreement. This is because parties are free to agree to whatever they want to, so far it is within the ambit of the law.

Just a little honest chit chat with a good friend, hope you like it, give me your feedback :)

CAN A DOMESTIC AGREEMENT BE ENFORCED?In the law of contract, There exist a presumption that social and domestic agreements are not enforceable, in other words they are not binding. The reason for this is that, it is presumed that there are no intentions to create legal relations when engaging in social and domestic agreements due to the nature of the agreements.This presumption is a rebuttable one. This means that there are instances where the court may infer an intention to create legal relations and enforce a domestic agreement.These instances may be regarded as the exceptions to the general presumption. These instances when proved or established, negates the presumption that social and domestic agreements are not binding.These instances are;When the parties within the domestic relationship were clearly not living in amity as at the time the agreement was made. This includes a situation where a couple are living apart as a result of a breakdown in the marriage. See the case of MERRITT V MERRITT.Again, a domestic agreement may be enforceable in situations were a party has made a great sacrifice in the process of making the agreement that it would be unfair and lead to great injustice if the agreement is not enforceable. In this instance, the great sacrifice represents consideration. See the case of PARKER V CLARK.Finally, a domestic agreement may be enforced by a court of law where evidence is adduced to show that parties to the contract  did intend to create legal relations in the terms of the agreement. This is because parties are free to agree to whatever they want to, so far it is within the ambit of the law.

CAN A DOMESTIC AGREEMENT BE ENFORCED?In the law of contract, There exist a presumption that social and domestic agreements are not enforceable, in other words they are not binding. The reason for this is that, it is presumed that there are no intentions to create legal relations when engaging in social and domestic agreements due to the nature of the agreements.This presumption is a rebuttable one. This means that there are instances where the court may infer an intention to create legal relations and enforce a domestic agreement.These instances may be regarded as the exceptions to the general presumption. These instances when proved or established, negates the presumption that social and domestic agreements are not binding.These instances are;When the parties within the domestic relationship were clearly not living in amity as at the time the agreement was made. This includes a situation where a couple are living apart as a result of a breakdown in the marriage. See the case of MERRITT V MERRITT.Again, a domestic agreement may be enforceable in situations were a party has made a great sacrifice in the process of making the agreement that it would be unfair and lead to great injustice if the agreement is not enforceable. In this instance, the great sacrifice represents consideration. See the case of PARKER V CLARK.Finally, a domestic agreement may be enforced by a court of law where evidence is adduced to show that parties to the contract  did intend to create legal relations in the terms of the agreement. This is because parties are free to agree to whatever they want to, so far it is within the ambit of the law.

â¡ï¸"Why OSPF Still Mattersâ€”Even in a FortiGate World"â¬…ï¸(Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø°Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ²Ø§Ù„ OSPF Ù…Ù‡Ù…Ø§Ù‹â€”Ø­ØªÙ‰ ÙÙŠ Ø¹Ø§Ù„Ù… FortiGate)In a world full of SD-WAN and cloud-centric networking, itâ€™s easy to overlook traditional protocols like OSPF. But last week, while redesigning a branch topology using FortiGate, I was reminded just how powerful and relevant OSPF still is.Hereâ€™s what happened:We had a multi-branch setup with dynamic routing needs, redundancy requirements, and a mandate to minimize manual configs. FortiGateâ€™s capabilities made the security part easyâ€”but OSPF stepped in to do the heavy lifting on routing.A few key takeaways:OSPFâ€™s link-state database gave us deep visibility into route changes.FortiGateâ€™s dynamic routing support is more robust than many give it credit for.Tuning OSPF cost and timers within FortiOS CLI still gives you precise control when needed.This isnâ€™t a debate between old vs. newâ€”itâ€™s about knowing what tool to use when.Curious to hear from others: Are you still leveraging OSPF with FortiGate? CAN A DOMESTIC AGREEMENT BE ENFORCED?In the law of contract, There exist a presumption that social and domestic agreements are not enforceable, in other words they are not binding. The reason for this is that, it is presumed that there are no intentions to create legal relations when engaging in social and domestic agreements due to the nature of the agreements.This presumption is a rebuttable one. This means that there are instances where the court may infer an intention to create legal relations and enforce a domestic agreement.These instances may be regarded as the exceptions to the general presumption. These instances when proved or established, negates the presumption that social and domestic agreements are not binding.These instances are;When the parties within the domestic relationship were clearly not living in amity as at the time the agreement was made. This includes a situation where a couple are living apart as a result of a breakdown in the marriage. See the case of MERRITT V MERRITT.Again, a domestic agreement may be enforceable in situations were a party has made a great sacrifice in the process of making the agreement that it would be unfair and lead to great injustice if the agreement is not enforceable. In this instance, the great sacrifice represents consideration. See the case of PARKER V CLARK.Finally, a domestic agreement may be enforced by a court of law where evidence is adduced to show that parties to the contract  did intend to create legal relations in the terms of the agreement. This is because parties are free to agree to whatever they want to, so far it is within the ambit of the law.

This task evaluates their ability to create a basic web service with CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations.#### Detailed Requirements:1. Create a New Blog Post: - HTTP Method: POST - Route: /api/posts - Request Body: JSON containing the required fields (e.g., title, content, author). - Validation: Ensure that title and content are not empty. - Response: Return the created post along with a success status code (e.g., 201 Created).2. Retrieve All Blog Posts: - HTTP Method: GET - Route: /api/posts - Response: Return a list of all blog posts in JSON format.3. Retrieve a Single Blog Post: - HTTP Method: GET - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Response: Return the specific blog post if it exists or an error status (e.g., 404 Not Found).4. Update a Blog Post: - HTTP Method: PUT - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Request Body: JSON with updated fields for the blog post. - Validation: Similar to creation, validate non-empty fields. - Response: Return the updated post or an appropriate error status if the post doesn't exist.5. Delete a Blog Post: - HTTP Method: DELETE - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Response: Return a success status for deletion or an error status if the post doesn't exist.#### Technical Choices:- ASP.NET Core: Use the latest version to leverage contemporary features and practices.- Entity Framework Core: Use for data access. An in-memory database can be used for simplicity during the test setup and execution.- Error Handling: Implement basic error handling to manage cases like invalid data, missing resources, etc.- Model Validation: Utilize ASP.NET Coreâ€™s built-in validation framework to ensure data integrity.#### Unit Testing:- Write at least two unit tests to verify the applicationâ€™s behavior. This could include tests for: - Successfully creating a blog post. - Fetching a non-existent blog post returns the appropriate error.#### Bonus Points:- Pagination: Implement pagination for the list of blog posts with query parameters like pageNumber and pageSize.- Logging: Introduce logging for critical operations to aid in monitoring and debugging. ASP.NET Core logging can be used to log to the console or a file.

Just a little honest chit chat with a good friend, hope you like it, give me your feedback :)

CAN A DOMESTIC AGREEMENT BE ENFORCED?In the law of contract, There exist a presumption that social and domestic agreements are not enforceable, in other words they are not binding. The reason for this is that, it is presumed that there are no intentions to create legal relations when engaging in social and domestic agreements due to the nature of the agreements.This presumption is a rebuttable one. This means that there are instances where the court may infer an intention to create legal relations and enforce a domestic agreement.These instances may be regarded as the exceptions to the general presumption. These instances when proved or established, negates the presumption that social and domestic agreements are not binding.These instances are;When the parties within the domestic relationship were clearly not living in amity as at the time the agreement was made. This includes a situation where a couple are living apart as a result of a breakdown in the marriage. See the case of MERRITT V MERRITT.Again, a domestic agreement may be enforceable in situations were a party has made a great sacrifice in the process of making the agreement that it would be unfair and lead to great injustice if the agreement is not enforceable. In this instance, the great sacrifice represents consideration. See the case of PARKER V CLARK.Finally, a domestic agreement may be enforced by a court of law where evidence is adduced to show that parties to the contract  did intend to create legal relations in the terms of the agreement. This is because parties are free to agree to whatever they want to, so far it is within the ambit of the law.

Sorting out the truth from the fiction around prenuptial agreements can help you make wise decisions about whether you need one, and how it may be enforced, modified, or discarded altogether. This task evaluates their ability to create a basic web service with CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations.#### Detailed Requirements:1. Create a New Blog Post: - HTTP Method: POST - Route: /api/posts - Request Body: JSON containing the required fields (e.g., title, content, author). - Validation: Ensure that title and content are not empty. - Response: Return the created post along with a success status code (e.g., 201 Created).2. Retrieve All Blog Posts: - HTTP Method: GET - Route: /api/posts - Response: Return a list of all blog posts in JSON format.3. Retrieve a Single Blog Post: - HTTP Method: GET - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Response: Return the specific blog post if it exists or an error status (e.g., 404 Not Found).4. Update a Blog Post: - HTTP Method: PUT - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Request Body: JSON with updated fields for the blog post. - Validation: Similar to creation, validate non-empty fields. - Response: Return the updated post or an appropriate error status if the post doesn't exist.5. Delete a Blog Post: - HTTP Method: DELETE - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Response: Return a success status for deletion or an error status if the post doesn't exist.#### Technical Choices:- ASP.NET Core: Use the latest version to leverage contemporary features and practices.- Entity Framework Core: Use for data access. An in-memory database can be used for simplicity during the test setup and execution.- Error Handling: Implement basic error handling to manage cases like invalid data, missing resources, etc.- Model Validation: Utilize ASP.NET Coreâ€™s built-in validation framework to ensure data integrity.#### Unit Testing:- Write at least two unit tests to verify the applicationâ€™s behavior. This could include tests for: - Successfully creating a blog post. - Fetching a non-existent blog post returns the appropriate error.#### Bonus Points:- Pagination: Implement pagination for the list of blog posts with query parameters like pageNumber and pageSize.- Logging: Introduce logging for critical operations to aid in monitoring and debugging. ASP.NET Core logging can be used to log to the console or a file.

CAN A DOMESTIC AGREEMENT BE ENFORCED?In the law of contract, There exist a presumption that social and domestic agreements are not enforceable, in other words they are not binding. The reason for this is that, it is presumed that there are no intentions to create legal relations when engaging in social and domestic agreements due to the nature of the agreements.This presumption is a rebuttable one. This means that there are instances where the court may infer an intention to create legal relations and enforce a domestic agreement.These instances may be regarded as the exceptions to the general presumption. These instances when proved or established, negates the presumption that social and domestic agreements are not binding.These instances are;When the parties within the domestic relationship were clearly not living in amity as at the time the agreement was made. This includes a situation where a couple are living apart as a result of a breakdown in the marriage. See the case of MERRITT V MERRITT.Again, a domestic agreement may be enforceable in situations were a party has made a great sacrifice in the process of making the agreement that it would be unfair and lead to great injustice if the agreement is not enforceable. In this instance, the great sacrifice represents consideration. See the case of PARKER V CLARK.Finally, a domestic agreement may be enforced by a court of law where evidence is adduced to show that parties to the contract  did intend to create legal relations in the terms of the agreement. This is because parties are free to agree to whatever they want to, so far it is within the ambit of the law.

Ø¯Ø± Ø§ÛŒÙ† Ù¾Ø³Øª Ù…ÛŒØ®ÙˆØ§Ù… ÛŒÚ© ØªØ³Ú© Ù…ØµØ§Ø­Ø¨Ù‡ Ø±Ø§ Ø´Ø±Ø­ Ø¨Ø¯Ù….Ø¹Ù„Øª Ø§Ù†ØªØ´Ø§Ø± Ø§ÛŒÙ† Ù¾Ø³Øª ØªÙˆÙ‡ÛŒÙ† Ø¨Ù‡ Ø²Ù…Ø§Ù† Ùˆ Ø´Ø¹ÙˆØ± Ø¨Ù†Ø¯Ù‡ Ø§Ø³Øª Ú©Ù‡ Ø¨Ø®Ø§Ø·Ø± Ù…ÙˆÙ‚Ø¹ÛŒØª Ù…Ú©Ø§Ù†ÛŒ Ø¨Ù†Ø¯Ù‡ Ø±Ø§ Ø±Ø¯ Ú©Ø±Ø¯Ù†Ø¯ ØªØ§Ø²Ù‡ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯ Ø§Ø² Ø§ÛŒÙ†Ú©Ù‡ ØªØ³Ú© Ø±Ø§ Ú©Ø§Ù…Ù„ Ù†ÙˆØ´ØªÙ… ğŸ˜…Ù‡Ù…ÙˆÙ† Ø§ÙˆÙ„ Ù…ÛŒØªÙˆÙ†Ø³ØªÙ† Ø¨Ú¯Ù† Ø¬Ù†Ø§Ø¨ Ù…ÙˆÙ‚Ø¹ÛŒØª Ù…Ú©Ø§Ù†ÛŒ Ø´Ù…Ø§ Ø¨Ø¯Ø±Ø¯ Ù…Ø§ Ù†Ù…ÛŒØ®ÙˆØ±Ù‡ØªØ³Ú©:### Task Breakdown#### Objective:The candidate must build a simple RESTful API for a blog application using ASP.NET Core. This task evaluates their ability to create a basic web service with CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations.#### Detailed Requirements:1. Create a New Blog Post: - HTTP Method: POST - Route: /api/posts - Request Body: JSON containing the required fields (e.g., title, content, author). - Validation: Ensure that title and content are not empty. - Response: Return the created post along with a success status code (e.g., 201 Created).2. Retrieve All Blog Posts: - HTTP Method: GET - Route: /api/posts - Response: Return a list of all blog posts in JSON format.3. Retrieve a Single Blog Post: - HTTP Method: GET - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Response: Return the specific blog post if it exists or an error status (e.g., 404 Not Found).4. Update a Blog Post: - HTTP Method: PUT - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Request Body: JSON with updated fields for the blog post. - Validation: Similar to creation, validate non-empty fields. - Response: Return the updated post or an appropriate error status if the post doesn't exist.5. Delete a Blog Post: - HTTP Method: DELETE - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Response: Return a success status for deletion or an error status if the post doesn't exist.#### Technical Choices:- ASP.NET Core: Use the latest version to leverage contemporary features and practices.- Entity Framework Core: Use for data access. An in-memory database can be used for simplicity during the test setup and execution.- Error Handling: Implement basic error handling to manage cases like invalid data, missing resources, etc.- Model Validation: Utilize ASP.NET Coreâ€™s built-in validation framework to ensure data integrity.#### Unit Testing:- Write at least two unit tests to verify the applicationâ€™s behavior. This could include tests for: - Successfully creating a blog post. - Fetching a non-existent blog post returns the appropriate error.#### Bonus Points:- Pagination: Implement pagination for the list of blog posts with query parameters like pageNumber and pageSize.- Logging: Introduce logging for critical operations to aid in monitoring and debugging. ASP.NET Core logging can be used to log to the console or a file.

CAN A DOMESTIC AGREEMENT BE ENFORCED?In the law of contract, There exist a presumption that social and domestic agreements are not enforceable, in other words they are not binding. The reason for this is that, it is presumed that there are no intentions to create legal relations when engaging in social and domestic agreements due to the nature of the agreements.This presumption is a rebuttable one. This means that there are instances where the court may infer an intention to create legal relations and enforce a domestic agreement.These instances may be regarded as the exceptions to the general presumption. These instances when proved or established, negates the presumption that social and domestic agreements are not binding.These instances are;When the parties within the domestic relationship were clearly not living in amity as at the time the agreement was made. This includes a situation where a couple are living apart as a result of a breakdown in the marriage. See the case of MERRITT V MERRITT.Again, a domestic agreement may be enforceable in situations were a party has made a great sacrifice in the process of making the agreement that it would be unfair and lead to great injustice if the agreement is not enforceable. In this instance, the great sacrifice represents consideration. See the case of PARKER V CLARK.Finally, a domestic agreement may be enforced by a court of law where evidence is adduced to show that parties to the contract  did intend to create legal relations in the terms of the agreement. This is because parties are free to agree to whatever they want to, so far it is within the ambit of the law.

Ø¯Ø± Ø§ÛŒÙ† Ù¾Ø³Øª Ù…ÛŒØ®ÙˆØ§Ù… ÛŒÚ© ØªØ³Ú© Ù…ØµØ§Ø­Ø¨Ù‡ Ø±Ø§ Ø´Ø±Ø­ Ø¨Ø¯Ù….Ø¹Ù„Øª Ø§Ù†ØªØ´Ø§Ø± Ø§ÛŒÙ† Ù¾Ø³Øª ØªÙˆÙ‡ÛŒÙ† Ø¨Ù‡ Ø²Ù…Ø§Ù† Ùˆ Ø´Ø¹ÙˆØ± Ø¨Ù†Ø¯Ù‡ Ø§Ø³Øª Ú©Ù‡ Ø¨Ø®Ø§Ø·Ø± Ù…ÙˆÙ‚Ø¹ÛŒØª Ù…Ú©Ø§Ù†ÛŒ Ø¨Ù†Ø¯Ù‡ Ø±Ø§ Ø±Ø¯ Ú©Ø±Ø¯Ù†Ø¯ ØªØ§Ø²Ù‡ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯ Ø§Ø² Ø§ÛŒÙ†Ú©Ù‡ ØªØ³Ú© Ø±Ø§ Ú©Ø§Ù…Ù„ Ù†ÙˆØ´ØªÙ… ğŸ˜…Ù‡Ù…ÙˆÙ† Ø§ÙˆÙ„ Ù…ÛŒØªÙˆÙ†Ø³ØªÙ† Ø¨Ú¯Ù† Ø¬Ù†Ø§Ø¨ Ù…ÙˆÙ‚Ø¹ÛŒØª Ù…Ú©Ø§Ù†ÛŒ Ø´Ù…Ø§ Ø¨Ø¯Ø±Ø¯ Ù…Ø§ Ù†Ù…ÛŒØ®ÙˆØ±Ù‡ØªØ³Ú©:### Task Breakdown#### Objective:The candidate must build a simple RESTful API for a blog application using ASP.NET Core. This task evaluates their ability to create a basic web service with CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations.#### Detailed Requirements:1. Create a New Blog Post: - HTTP Method: POST - Route: /api/posts - Request Body: JSON containing the required fields (e.g., title, content, author). - Validation: Ensure that title and content are not empty. - Response: Return the created post along with a success status code (e.g., 201 Created).2. Retrieve All Blog Posts: - HTTP Method: GET - Route: /api/posts - Response: Return a list of all blog posts in JSON format.3. Retrieve a Single Blog Post: - HTTP Method: GET - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Response: Return the specific blog post if it exists or an error status (e.g., 404 Not Found).4. Update a Blog Post: - HTTP Method: PUT - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Request Body: JSON with updated fields for the blog post. - Validation: Similar to creation, validate non-empty fields. - Response: Return the updated post or an appropriate error status if the post doesn't exist.5. Delete a Blog Post: - HTTP Method: DELETE - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Response: Return a success status for deletion or an error status if the post doesn't exist.#### Technical Choices:- ASP.NET Core: Use the latest version to leverage contemporary features and practices.- Entity Framework Core: Use for data access. An in-memory database can be used for simplicity during the test setup and execution.- Error Handling: Implement basic error handling to manage cases like invalid data, missing resources, etc.- Model Validation: Utilize ASP.NET Coreâ€™s built-in validation framework to ensure data integrity.#### Unit Testing:- Write at least two unit tests to verify the applicationâ€™s behavior. This could include tests for: - Successfully creating a blog post. - Fetching a non-existent blog post returns the appropriate error.#### Bonus Points:- Pagination: Implement pagination for the list of blog posts with query parameters like pageNumber and pageSize.- Logging: Introduce logging for critical operations to aid in monitoring and debugging. ASP.NET Core logging can be used to log to the console or a file.

â¡ï¸"Why OSPF Still Mattersâ€”Even in a FortiGate World"â¬…ï¸(Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø°Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ²Ø§Ù„ OSPF Ù…Ù‡Ù…Ø§Ù‹â€”Ø­ØªÙ‰ ÙÙŠ Ø¹Ø§Ù„Ù… FortiGate)In a world full of SD-WAN and cloud-centric networking, itâ€™s easy to overlook traditional protocols like OSPF. But last week, while redesigning a branch topology using FortiGate, I was reminded just how powerful and relevant OSPF still is.Hereâ€™s what happened:We had a multi-branch setup with dynamic routing needs, redundancy requirements, and a mandate to minimize manual configs. FortiGateâ€™s capabilities made the security part easyâ€”but OSPF stepped in to do the heavy lifting on routing.A few key takeaways:OSPFâ€™s link-state database gave us deep visibility into route changes.FortiGateâ€™s dynamic routing support is more robust than many give it credit for.Tuning OSPF cost and timers within FortiOS CLI still gives you precise control when needed.This isnâ€™t a debate between old vs. newâ€”itâ€™s about knowing what tool to use when.Curious to hear from others: Are you still leveraging OSPF with FortiGate? How are you balancing legacy protocols with modern network needs?Letâ€™s talk tech that actually works in production.In Arabic: â¬…ï¸ Ù„Ù…Ø§Ø°Ø§ Ù„Ø§ ÙŠØ²Ø§Ù„ OSPF Ù…Ù‡Ù…Ø§Ù‹â€”Ø­ØªÙ‰ ÙÙŠ Ø¹Ø§Ù„Ù… FortiGate:ÙÙŠ Ø¹Ø§Ù„Ù… Ù…Ù„ÙŠØ¡ Ø¨ØªÙ‚Ù†ÙŠØ§Øª SD-WAN ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø´Ø¨ÙƒØ§Øª Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø±ÙƒØ²Ø© Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ø³Ø­Ø§Ø¨Ø©ØŒ Ù…Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù‡Ù„ Ø£Ù† Ù†ØªØºØ§Ø¶Ù‰ Ø¹Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¨Ø±ÙˆØªÙˆÙƒÙˆÙ„Ø§Øª Ø§Ù„ØªÙ‚Ù„ÙŠØ¯ÙŠØ© Ù…Ø«Ù„ OSPF. CAN A DOMESTIC AGREEMENT BE ENFORCED?In the law of contract, There exist a presumption that social and domestic agreements are not enforceable, in other words they are not binding. The reason for this is that, it is presumed that there are no intentions to create legal relations when engaging in social and domestic agreements due to the nature of the agreements.This presumption is a rebuttable one. This means that there are instances where the court may infer an intention to create legal relations and enforce a domestic agreement.These instances may be regarded as the exceptions to the general presumption. These instances when proved or established, negates the presumption that social and domestic agreements are not binding.These instances are;When the parties within the domestic relationship were clearly not living in amity as at the time the agreement was made. This includes a situation where a couple are living apart as a result of a breakdown in the marriage. See the case of MERRITT V MERRITT.Again, a domestic agreement may be enforceable in situations were a party has made a great sacrifice in the process of making the agreement that it would be unfair and lead to great injustice if the agreement is not enforceable. In this instance, the great sacrifice represents consideration. See the case of PARKER V CLARK.Finally, a domestic agreement may be enforced by a court of law where evidence is adduced to show that parties to the contract  did intend to create legal relations in the terms of the agreement. This is because parties are free to agree to whatever they want to, so far it is within the ambit of the law.

Ø¯Ø± Ø§ÛŒÙ† Ù¾Ø³Øª Ù…ÛŒØ®ÙˆØ§Ù… ÛŒÚ© ØªØ³Ú© Ù…ØµØ§Ø­Ø¨Ù‡ Ø±Ø§ Ø´Ø±Ø­ Ø¨Ø¯Ù….Ø¹Ù„Øª Ø§Ù†ØªØ´Ø§Ø± Ø§ÛŒÙ† Ù¾Ø³Øª ØªÙˆÙ‡ÛŒÙ† Ø¨Ù‡ Ø²Ù…Ø§Ù† Ùˆ Ø´Ø¹ÙˆØ± Ø¨Ù†Ø¯Ù‡ Ø§Ø³Øª Ú©Ù‡ Ø¨Ø®Ø§Ø·Ø± Ù…ÙˆÙ‚Ø¹ÛŒØª Ù…Ú©Ø§Ù†ÛŒ Ø¨Ù†Ø¯Ù‡ Ø±Ø§ Ø±Ø¯ Ú©Ø±Ø¯Ù†Ø¯ ØªØ§Ø²Ù‡ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯ Ø§Ø² Ø§ÛŒÙ†Ú©Ù‡ ØªØ³Ú© Ø±Ø§ Ú©Ø§Ù…Ù„ Ù†ÙˆØ´ØªÙ… ğŸ˜…Ù‡Ù…ÙˆÙ† Ø§ÙˆÙ„ Ù…ÛŒØªÙˆÙ†Ø³ØªÙ† Ø¨Ú¯Ù† Ø¬Ù†Ø§Ø¨ Ù…ÙˆÙ‚Ø¹ÛŒØª Ù…Ú©Ø§Ù†ÛŒ Ø´Ù…Ø§ Ø¨Ø¯Ø±Ø¯ Ù…Ø§ Ù†Ù…ÛŒØ®ÙˆØ±Ù‡ØªØ³Ú©:### Task Breakdown#### Objective:The candidate must build a simple RESTful API for a blog application using ASP.NET Core. This task evaluates their ability to create a basic web service with CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations.#### Detailed Requirements:1. Create a New Blog Post: - HTTP Method: POST - Route: /api/posts - Request Body: JSON containing the required fields (e.g., title, content, author). - Validation: Ensure that title and content are not empty. - Response: Return the created post along with a success status code (e.g., 201 Created).2. Retrieve All Blog Posts: - HTTP Method: GET - Route: /api/posts - Response: Return a list of all blog posts in JSON format.3. Retrieve a Single Blog Post: - HTTP Method: GET - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Response: Return the specific blog post if it exists or an error status (e.g., 404 Not Found).4. Update a Blog Post: - HTTP Method: PUT - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Request Body: JSON with updated fields for the blog post. - Validation: Similar to creation, validate non-empty fields. - Response: Return the updated post or an appropriate error status if the post doesn't exist.5. Delete a Blog Post: - HTTP Method: DELETE - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Response: Return a success status for deletion or an error status if the post doesn't exist.#### Technical Choices:- ASP.NET Core: Use the latest version to leverage contemporary features and practices.- Entity Framework Core: Use for data access. An in-memory database can be used for simplicity during the test setup and execution.- Error Handling: Implement basic error handling to manage cases like invalid data, missing resources, etc.- Model Validation: Utilize ASP.NET Coreâ€™s built-in validation framework to ensure data integrity.#### Unit Testing:- Write at least two unit tests to verify the applicationâ€™s behavior. This could include tests for: - Successfully creating a blog post. - Fetching a non-existent blog post returns the appropriate error.#### Bonus Points:- Pagination: Implement pagination for the list of blog posts with query parameters like pageNumber and pageSize.- Logging: Introduce logging for critical operations to aid in monitoring and debugging. ASP.NET Core logging can be used to log to the console or a file.

CAN A DOMESTIC AGREEMENT BE ENFORCED?In the law of contract, There exist a presumption that social and domestic agreements are not enforceable, in other words they are not binding. The reason for this is that, it is presumed that there are no intentions to create legal relations when engaging in social and domestic agreements due to the nature of the agreements.This presumption is a rebuttable one. This means that there are instances where the court may infer an intention to create legal relations and enforce a domestic agreement.These instances may be regarded as the exceptions to the general presumption. These instances when proved or established, negates the presumption that social and domestic agreements are not binding.These instances are;When the parties within the domestic relationship were clearly not living in amity as at the time the agreement was made. This includes a situation where a couple are living apart as a result of a breakdown in the marriage. See the case of MERRITT V MERRITT.Again, a domestic agreement may be enforceable in situations were a party has made a great sacrifice in the process of making the agreement that it would be unfair and lead to great injustice if the agreement is not enforceable. In this instance, the great sacrifice represents consideration. See the case of PARKER V CLARK.Finally, a domestic agreement may be enforced by a court of law where evidence is adduced to show that parties to the contract  did intend to create legal relations in the terms of the agreement. This is because parties are free to agree to whatever they want to, so far it is within the ambit of the law.

This task evaluates their ability to create a basic web service with CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations.#### Detailed Requirements:1. Create a New Blog Post: - HTTP Method: POST - Route: /api/posts - Request Body: JSON containing the required fields (e.g., title, content, author). - Validation: Ensure that title and content are not empty. - Response: Return the created post along with a success status code (e.g., 201 Created).2. Retrieve All Blog Posts: - HTTP Method: GET - Route: /api/posts - Response: Return a list of all blog posts in JSON format.3. Retrieve a Single Blog Post: - HTTP Method: GET - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Response: Return the specific blog post if it exists or an error status (e.g., 404 Not Found).4. Update a Blog Post: - HTTP Method: PUT - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Request Body: JSON with updated fields for the blog post. - Validation: Similar to creation, validate non-empty fields. - Response: Return the updated post or an appropriate error status if the post doesn't exist.5. Delete a Blog Post: - HTTP Method: DELETE - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Response: Return a success status for deletion or an error status if the post doesn't exist.#### Technical Choices:- ASP.NET Core: Use the latest version to leverage contemporary features and practices.- Entity Framework Core: Use for data access. An in-memory database can be used for simplicity during the test setup and execution.- Error Handling: Implement basic error handling to manage cases like invalid data, missing resources, etc.- Model Validation: Utilize ASP.NET Coreâ€™s built-in validation framework to ensure data integrity.#### Unit Testing:- Write at least two unit tests to verify the applicationâ€™s behavior. This could include tests for: - Successfully creating a blog post. - Fetching a non-existent blog post returns the appropriate error.#### Bonus Points:- Pagination: Implement pagination for the list of blog posts with query parameters like pageNumber and pageSize.- Logging: Introduce logging for critical operations to aid in monitoring and debugging. ASP.NET Core logging can be used to log to the console or a file.

But last week, while redesigning a branch topology using FortiGate, I was reminded just how powerful and relevant OSPF still is.Hereâ€™s what happened:We had a multi-branch setup with dynamic routing needs, redundancy requirements, and a mandate to minimize manual configs. FortiGateâ€™s capabilities made the security part easyâ€”but OSPF stepped in to do the heavy lifting on routing.A few key takeaways:OSPFâ€™s link-state database gave us deep visibility into route changes.FortiGateâ€™s dynamic routing support is more robust than many give it credit for.Tuning OSPF cost and timers within FortiOS CLI still gives you precise control when needed.This isnâ€™t a debate between old vs. newâ€”itâ€™s about knowing what tool to use when.Curious to hear from others: Are you still leveraging OSPF with FortiGate? CAN A DOMESTIC AGREEMENT BE ENFORCED?In the law of contract, There exist a presumption that social and domestic agreements are not enforceable, in other words they are not binding. The reason for this is that, it is presumed that there are no intentions to create legal relations when engaging in social and domestic agreements due to the nature of the agreements.This presumption is a rebuttable one. This means that there are instances where the court may infer an intention to create legal relations and enforce a domestic agreement.These instances may be regarded as the exceptions to the general presumption. These instances when proved or established, negates the presumption that social and domestic agreements are not binding.These instances are;When the parties within the domestic relationship were clearly not living in amity as at the time the agreement was made. This includes a situation where a couple are living apart as a result of a breakdown in the marriage. See the case of MERRITT V MERRITT.Again, a domestic agreement may be enforceable in situations were a party has made a great sacrifice in the process of making the agreement that it would be unfair and lead to great injustice if the agreement is not enforceable. In this instance, the great sacrifice represents consideration. See the case of PARKER V CLARK.Finally, a domestic agreement may be enforced by a court of law where evidence is adduced to show that parties to the contract  did intend to create legal relations in the terms of the agreement. This is because parties are free to agree to whatever they want to, so far it is within the ambit of the law.

Ø¯Ø± Ø§ÛŒÙ† Ù¾Ø³Øª Ù…ÛŒØ®ÙˆØ§Ù… ÛŒÚ© ØªØ³Ú© Ù…ØµØ§Ø­Ø¨Ù‡ Ø±Ø§ Ø´Ø±Ø­ Ø¨Ø¯Ù….Ø¹Ù„Øª Ø§Ù†ØªØ´Ø§Ø± Ø§ÛŒÙ† Ù¾Ø³Øª ØªÙˆÙ‡ÛŒÙ† Ø¨Ù‡ Ø²Ù…Ø§Ù† Ùˆ Ø´Ø¹ÙˆØ± Ø¨Ù†Ø¯Ù‡ Ø§Ø³Øª Ú©Ù‡ Ø¨Ø®Ø§Ø·Ø± Ù…ÙˆÙ‚Ø¹ÛŒØª Ù…Ú©Ø§Ù†ÛŒ Ø¨Ù†Ø¯Ù‡ Ø±Ø§ Ø±Ø¯ Ú©Ø±Ø¯Ù†Ø¯ ØªØ§Ø²Ù‡ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯ Ø§Ø² Ø§ÛŒÙ†Ú©Ù‡ ØªØ³Ú© Ø±Ø§ Ú©Ø§Ù…Ù„ Ù†ÙˆØ´ØªÙ… ğŸ˜…Ù‡Ù…ÙˆÙ† Ø§ÙˆÙ„ Ù…ÛŒØªÙˆÙ†Ø³ØªÙ† Ø¨Ú¯Ù† Ø¬Ù†Ø§Ø¨ Ù…ÙˆÙ‚Ø¹ÛŒØª Ù…Ú©Ø§Ù†ÛŒ Ø´Ù…Ø§ Ø¨Ø¯Ø±Ø¯ Ù…Ø§ Ù†Ù…ÛŒØ®ÙˆØ±Ù‡ØªØ³Ú©:### Task Breakdown#### Objective:The candidate must build a simple RESTful API for a blog application using ASP.NET Core. This task evaluates their ability to create a basic web service with CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations.#### Detailed Requirements:1. Create a New Blog Post: - HTTP Method: POST - Route: /api/posts - Request Body: JSON containing the required fields (e.g., title, content, author). - Validation: Ensure that title and content are not empty. - Response: Return the created post along with a success status code (e.g., 201 Created).2. Retrieve All Blog Posts: - HTTP Method: GET - Route: /api/posts - Response: Return a list of all blog posts in JSON format.3. Retrieve a Single Blog Post: - HTTP Method: GET - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Response: Return the specific blog post if it exists or an error status (e.g., 404 Not Found).4. Update a Blog Post: - HTTP Method: PUT - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Request Body: JSON with updated fields for the blog post. - Validation: Similar to creation, validate non-empty fields. - Response: Return the updated post or an appropriate error status if the post doesn't exist.5. Delete a Blog Post: - HTTP Method: DELETE - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Response: Return a success status for deletion or an error status if the post doesn't exist.#### Technical Choices:- ASP.NET Core: Use the latest version to leverage contemporary features and practices.- Entity Framework Core: Use for data access. An in-memory database can be used for simplicity during the test setup and execution.- Error Handling: Implement basic error handling to manage cases like invalid data, missing resources, etc.- Model Validation: Utilize ASP.NET Coreâ€™s built-in validation framework to ensure data integrity.#### Unit Testing:- Write at least two unit tests to verify the applicationâ€™s behavior. This could include tests for: - Successfully creating a blog post. - Fetching a non-existent blog post returns the appropriate error.#### Bonus Points:- Pagination: Implement pagination for the list of blog posts with query parameters like pageNumber and pageSize.- Logging: Introduce logging for critical operations to aid in monitoring and debugging. ASP.NET Core logging can be used to log to the console or a file.

CAN A DOMESTIC AGREEMENT BE ENFORCED?In the law of contract, There exist a presumption that social and domestic agreements are not enforceable, in other words they are not binding. The reason for this is that, it is presumed that there are no intentions to create legal relations when engaging in social and domestic agreements due to the nature of the agreements.This presumption is a rebuttable one. This means that there are instances where the court may infer an intention to create legal relations and enforce a domestic agreement.These instances may be regarded as the exceptions to the general presumption. These instances when proved or established, negates the presumption that social and domestic agreements are not binding.These instances are;When the parties within the domestic relationship were clearly not living in amity as at the time the agreement was made. This includes a situation where a couple are living apart as a result of a breakdown in the marriage. See the case of MERRITT V MERRITT.Again, a domestic agreement may be enforceable in situations were a party has made a great sacrifice in the process of making the agreement that it would be unfair and lead to great injustice if the agreement is not enforceable. In this instance, the great sacrifice represents consideration. See the case of PARKER V CLARK.Finally, a domestic agreement may be enforced by a court of law where evidence is adduced to show that parties to the contract  did intend to create legal relations in the terms of the agreement. This is because parties are free to agree to whatever they want to, so far it is within the ambit of the law.

Ø¯Ø± Ø§ÛŒÙ† Ù¾Ø³Øª Ù…ÛŒØ®ÙˆØ§Ù… ÛŒÚ© ØªØ³Ú© Ù…ØµØ§Ø­Ø¨Ù‡ Ø±Ø§ Ø´Ø±Ø­ Ø¨Ø¯Ù….Ø¹Ù„Øª Ø§Ù†ØªØ´Ø§Ø± Ø§ÛŒÙ† Ù¾Ø³Øª ØªÙˆÙ‡ÛŒÙ† Ø¨Ù‡ Ø²Ù…Ø§Ù† Ùˆ Ø´Ø¹ÙˆØ± Ø¨Ù†Ø¯Ù‡ Ø§Ø³Øª Ú©Ù‡ Ø¨Ø®Ø§Ø·Ø± Ù…ÙˆÙ‚Ø¹ÛŒØª Ù…Ú©Ø§Ù†ÛŒ Ø¨Ù†Ø¯Ù‡ Ø±Ø§ Ø±Ø¯ Ú©Ø±Ø¯Ù†Ø¯ ØªØ§Ø²Ù‡ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯ Ø§Ø² Ø§ÛŒÙ†Ú©Ù‡ ØªØ³Ú© Ø±Ø§ Ú©Ø§Ù…Ù„ Ù†ÙˆØ´ØªÙ… ğŸ˜…Ù‡Ù…ÙˆÙ† Ø§ÙˆÙ„ Ù…ÛŒØªÙˆÙ†Ø³ØªÙ† Ø¨Ú¯Ù† Ø¬Ù†Ø§Ø¨ Ù…ÙˆÙ‚Ø¹ÛŒØª Ù…Ú©Ø§Ù†ÛŒ Ø´Ù…Ø§ Ø¨Ø¯Ø±Ø¯ Ù…Ø§ Ù†Ù…ÛŒØ®ÙˆØ±Ù‡ØªØ³Ú©:### Task Breakdown#### Objective:The candidate must build a simple RESTful API for a blog application using ASP.NET Core. This task evaluates their ability to create a basic web service with CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations.#### Detailed Requirements:1. Create a New Blog Post: - HTTP Method: POST - Route: /api/posts - Request Body: JSON containing the required fields (e.g., title, content, author). - Validation: Ensure that title and content are not empty. - Response: Return the created post along with a success status code (e.g., 201 Created).2. Retrieve All Blog Posts: - HTTP Method: GET - Route: /api/posts - Response: Return a list of all blog posts in JSON format.3. Retrieve a Single Blog Post: - HTTP Method: GET - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Response: Return the specific blog post if it exists or an error status (e.g., 404 Not Found).4. Update a Blog Post: - HTTP Method: PUT - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Request Body: JSON with updated fields for the blog post. - Validation: Similar to creation, validate non-empty fields. - Response: Return the updated post or an appropriate error status if the post doesn't exist.5. Delete a Blog Post: - HTTP Method: DELETE - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Response: Return a success status for deletion or an error status if the post doesn't exist.#### Technical Choices:- ASP.NET Core: Use the latest version to leverage contemporary features and practices.- Entity Framework Core: Use for data access. An in-memory database can be used for simplicity during the test setup and execution.- Error Handling: Implement basic error handling to manage cases like invalid data, missing resources, etc.- Model Validation: Utilize ASP.NET Coreâ€™s built-in validation framework to ensure data integrity.#### Unit Testing:- Write at least two unit tests to verify the applicationâ€™s behavior. This could include tests for: - Successfully creating a blog post. - Fetching a non-existent blog post returns the appropriate error.#### Bonus Points:- Pagination: Implement pagination for the list of blog posts with query parameters like pageNumber and pageSize.- Logging: Introduce logging for critical operations to aid in monitoring and debugging. ASP.NET Core logging can be used to log to the console or a file.

CAN A DOMESTIC AGREEMENT BE ENFORCED?In the law of contract, There exist a presumption that social and domestic agreements are not enforceable, in other words they are not binding. The reason for this is that, it is presumed that there are no intentions to create legal relations when engaging in social and domestic agreements due to the nature of the agreements.This presumption is a rebuttable one. This means that there are instances where the court may infer an intention to create legal relations and enforce a domestic agreement.These instances may be regarded as the exceptions to the general presumption. These instances when proved or established, negates the presumption that social and domestic agreements are not binding.These instances are;When the parties within the domestic relationship were clearly not living in amity as at the time the agreement was made. This includes a situation where a couple are living apart as a result of a breakdown in the marriage. See the case of MERRITT V MERRITT.Again, a domestic agreement may be enforceable in situations were a party has made a great sacrifice in the process of making the agreement that it would be unfair and lead to great injustice if the agreement is not enforceable. In this instance, the great sacrifice represents consideration. See the case of PARKER V CLARK.Finally, a domestic agreement may be enforced by a court of law where evidence is adduced to show that parties to the contract  did intend to create legal relations in the terms of the agreement. This is because parties are free to agree to whatever they want to, so far it is within the ambit of the law.

Ø¯Ø± Ø§ÛŒÙ† Ù¾Ø³Øª Ù…ÛŒØ®ÙˆØ§Ù… ÛŒÚ© ØªØ³Ú© Ù…ØµØ§Ø­Ø¨Ù‡ Ø±Ø§ Ø´Ø±Ø­ Ø¨Ø¯Ù….Ø¹Ù„Øª Ø§Ù†ØªØ´Ø§Ø± Ø§ÛŒÙ† Ù¾Ø³Øª ØªÙˆÙ‡ÛŒÙ† Ø¨Ù‡ Ø²Ù…Ø§Ù† Ùˆ Ø´Ø¹ÙˆØ± Ø¨Ù†Ø¯Ù‡ Ø§Ø³Øª Ú©Ù‡ Ø¨Ø®Ø§Ø·Ø± Ù…ÙˆÙ‚Ø¹ÛŒØª Ù…Ú©Ø§Ù†ÛŒ Ø¨Ù†Ø¯Ù‡ Ø±Ø§ Ø±Ø¯ Ú©Ø±Ø¯Ù†Ø¯ ØªØ§Ø²Ù‡ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯ Ø§Ø² Ø§ÛŒÙ†Ú©Ù‡ ØªØ³Ú© Ø±Ø§ Ú©Ø§Ù…Ù„ Ù†ÙˆØ´ØªÙ… ğŸ˜…Ù‡Ù…ÙˆÙ† Ø§ÙˆÙ„ Ù…ÛŒØªÙˆÙ†Ø³ØªÙ† Ø¨Ú¯Ù† Ø¬Ù†Ø§Ø¨ Ù…ÙˆÙ‚Ø¹ÛŒØª Ù…Ú©Ø§Ù†ÛŒ Ø´Ù…Ø§ Ø¨Ø¯Ø±Ø¯ Ù…Ø§ Ù†Ù…ÛŒØ®ÙˆØ±Ù‡ØªØ³Ú©:### Task Breakdown#### Objective:The candidate must build a simple RESTful API for a blog application using ASP.NET Core. This task evaluates their ability to create a basic web service with CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations.#### Detailed Requirements:1. Create a New Blog Post: - HTTP Method: POST - Route: /api/posts - Request Body: JSON containing the required fields (e.g., title, content, author). - Validation: Ensure that title and content are not empty. - Response: Return the created post along with a success status code (e.g., 201 Created).2. Retrieve All Blog Posts: - HTTP Method: GET - Route: /api/posts - Response: Return a list of all blog posts in JSON format.3. Retrieve a Single Blog Post: - HTTP Method: GET - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Response: Return the specific blog post if it exists or an error status (e.g., 404 Not Found).4. Update a Blog Post: - HTTP Method: PUT - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Request Body: JSON with updated fields for the blog post. - Validation: Similar to creation, validate non-empty fields. - Response: Return the updated post or an appropriate error status if the post doesn't exist.5. Delete a Blog Post: - HTTP Method: DELETE - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Response: Return a success status for deletion or an error status if the post doesn't exist.#### Technical Choices:- ASP.NET Core: Use the latest version to leverage contemporary features and practices.- Entity Framework Core: Use for data access. An in-memory database can be used for simplicity during the test setup and execution.- Error Handling: Implement basic error handling to manage cases like invalid data, missing resources, etc.- Model Validation: Utilize ASP.NET Coreâ€™s built-in validation framework to ensure data integrity.#### Unit Testing:- Write at least two unit tests to verify the applicationâ€™s behavior. This could include tests for: - Successfully creating a blog post. - Fetching a non-existent blog post returns the appropriate error.#### Bonus Points:- Pagination: Implement pagination for the list of blog posts with query parameters like pageNumber and pageSize.- Logging: Introduce logging for critical operations to aid in monitoring and debugging. ASP.NET Core logging can be used to log to the console or a file.

CAN A DOMESTIC AGREEMENT BE ENFORCED?In the law of contract, There exist a presumption that social and domestic agreements are not enforceable, in other words they are not binding. The reason for this is that, it is presumed that there are no intentions to create legal relations when engaging in social and domestic agreements due to the nature of the agreements.This presumption is a rebuttable one. This means that there are instances where the court may infer an intention to create legal relations and enforce a domestic agreement.These instances may be regarded as the exceptions to the general presumption. These instances when proved or established, negates the presumption that social and domestic agreements are not binding.These instances are;When the parties within the domestic relationship were clearly not living in amity as at the time the agreement was made. This includes a situation where a couple are living apart as a result of a breakdown in the marriage. See the case of MERRITT V MERRITT.Again, a domestic agreement may be enforceable in situations were a party has made a great sacrifice in the process of making the agreement that it would be unfair and lead to great injustice if the agreement is not enforceable. In this instance, the great sacrifice represents consideration. See the case of PARKER V CLARK.Finally, a domestic agreement may be enforced by a court of law where evidence is adduced to show that parties to the contract  did intend to create legal relations in the terms of the agreement. This is because parties are free to agree to whatever they want to, so far it is within the ambit of the law.

Ø¯Ø± Ø§ÛŒÙ† Ù¾Ø³Øª Ù…ÛŒØ®ÙˆØ§Ù… ÛŒÚ© ØªØ³Ú© Ù…ØµØ§Ø­Ø¨Ù‡ Ø±Ø§ Ø´Ø±Ø­ Ø¨Ø¯Ù….Ø¹Ù„Øª Ø§Ù†ØªØ´Ø§Ø± Ø§ÛŒÙ† Ù¾Ø³Øª ØªÙˆÙ‡ÛŒÙ† Ø¨Ù‡ Ø²Ù…Ø§Ù† Ùˆ Ø´Ø¹ÙˆØ± Ø¨Ù†Ø¯Ù‡ Ø§Ø³Øª Ú©Ù‡ Ø¨Ø®Ø§Ø·Ø± Ù…ÙˆÙ‚Ø¹ÛŒØª Ù…Ú©Ø§Ù†ÛŒ Ø¨Ù†Ø¯Ù‡ Ø±Ø§ Ø±Ø¯ Ú©Ø±Ø¯Ù†Ø¯ ØªØ§Ø²Ù‡ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯ Ø§Ø² Ø§ÛŒÙ†Ú©Ù‡ ØªØ³Ú© Ø±Ø§ Ú©Ø§Ù…Ù„ Ù†ÙˆØ´ØªÙ… ğŸ˜…Ù‡Ù…ÙˆÙ† Ø§ÙˆÙ„ Ù…ÛŒØªÙˆÙ†Ø³ØªÙ† Ø¨Ú¯Ù† Ø¬Ù†Ø§Ø¨ Ù…ÙˆÙ‚Ø¹ÛŒØª Ù…Ú©Ø§Ù†ÛŒ Ø´Ù…Ø§ Ø¨Ø¯Ø±Ø¯ Ù…Ø§ Ù†Ù…ÛŒØ®ÙˆØ±Ù‡ØªØ³Ú©:### Task Breakdown#### Objective:The candidate must build a simple RESTful API for a blog application using ASP.NET Core. This task evaluates their ability to create a basic web service with CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations.#### Detailed Requirements:1. Create a New Blog Post: - HTTP Method: POST - Route: /api/posts - Request Body: JSON containing the required fields (e.g., title, content, author). - Validation: Ensure that title and content are not empty. - Response: Return the created post along with a success status code (e.g., 201 Created).2. Retrieve All Blog Posts: - HTTP Method: GET - Route: /api/posts - Response: Return a list of all blog posts in JSON format.3. Retrieve a Single Blog Post: - HTTP Method: GET - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Response: Return the specific blog post if it exists or an error status (e.g., 404 Not Found).4. Update a Blog Post: - HTTP Method: PUT - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Request Body: JSON with updated fields for the blog post. - Validation: Similar to creation, validate non-empty fields. - Response: Return the updated post or an appropriate error status if the post doesn't exist.5. Delete a Blog Post: - HTTP Method: DELETE - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Response: Return a success status for deletion or an error status if the post doesn't exist.#### Technical Choices:- ASP.NET Core: Use the latest version to leverage contemporary features and practices.- Entity Framework Core: Use for data access. An in-memory database can be used for simplicity during the test setup and execution.- Error Handling: Implement basic error handling to manage cases like invalid data, missing resources, etc.- Model Validation: Utilize ASP.NET Coreâ€™s built-in validation framework to ensure data integrity.#### Unit Testing:- Write at least two unit tests to verify the applicationâ€™s behavior. This could include tests for: - Successfully creating a blog post. - Fetching a non-existent blog post returns the appropriate error.#### Bonus Points:- Pagination: Implement pagination for the list of blog posts with query parameters like pageNumber and pageSize.- Logging: Introduce logging for critical operations to aid in monitoring and debugging. ASP.NET Core logging can be used to log to the console or a file.

But last week, while redesigning a branch topology using FortiGate, I was reminded just how powerful and relevant OSPF still is.Hereâ€™s what happened:We had a multi-branch setup with dynamic routing needs, redundancy requirements, and a mandate to minimize manual configs. FortiGateâ€™s capabilities made the security part easyâ€”but OSPF stepped in to do the heavy lifting on routing.A few key takeaways:OSPFâ€™s link-state database gave us deep visibility into route changes.FortiGateâ€™s dynamic routing support is more robust than many give it credit for.Tuning OSPF cost and timers within FortiOS CLI still gives you precise control when needed.This isnâ€™t a debate between old vs. newâ€”itâ€™s about knowing what tool to use when.Curious to hear from others: Are you still leveraging OSPF with FortiGate? CAN A DOMESTIC AGREEMENT BE ENFORCED?In the law of contract, There exist a presumption that social and domestic agreements are not enforceable, in other words they are not binding. The reason for this is that, it is presumed that there are no intentions to create legal relations when engaging in social and domestic agreements due to the nature of the agreements.This presumption is a rebuttable one. This means that there are instances where the court may infer an intention to create legal relations and enforce a domestic agreement.These instances may be regarded as the exceptions to the general presumption. These instances when proved or established, negates the presumption that social and domestic agreements are not binding.These instances are;When the parties within the domestic relationship were clearly not living in amity as at the time the agreement was made. This includes a situation where a couple are living apart as a result of a breakdown in the marriage. See the case of MERRITT V MERRITT.Again, a domestic agreement may be enforceable in situations were a party has made a great sacrifice in the process of making the agreement that it would be unfair and lead to great injustice if the agreement is not enforceable. In this instance, the great sacrifice represents consideration. See the case of PARKER V CLARK.Finally, a domestic agreement may be enforced by a court of law where evidence is adduced to show that parties to the contract  did intend to create legal relations in the terms of the agreement. This is because parties are free to agree to whatever they want to, so far it is within the ambit of the law.

Ø¯Ø± Ø§ÛŒÙ† Ù¾Ø³Øª Ù…ÛŒØ®ÙˆØ§Ù… ÛŒÚ© ØªØ³Ú© Ù…ØµØ§Ø­Ø¨Ù‡ Ø±Ø§ Ø´Ø±Ø­ Ø¨Ø¯Ù….Ø¹Ù„Øª Ø§Ù†ØªØ´Ø§Ø± Ø§ÛŒÙ† Ù¾Ø³Øª ØªÙˆÙ‡ÛŒÙ† Ø¨Ù‡ Ø²Ù…Ø§Ù† Ùˆ Ø´Ø¹ÙˆØ± Ø¨Ù†Ø¯Ù‡ Ø§Ø³Øª Ú©Ù‡ Ø¨Ø®Ø§Ø·Ø± Ù…ÙˆÙ‚Ø¹ÛŒØª Ù…Ú©Ø§Ù†ÛŒ Ø¨Ù†Ø¯Ù‡ Ø±Ø§ Ø±Ø¯ Ú©Ø±Ø¯Ù†Ø¯ ØªØ§Ø²Ù‡ Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯ Ø§Ø² Ø§ÛŒÙ†Ú©Ù‡ ØªØ³Ú© Ø±Ø§ Ú©Ø§Ù…Ù„ Ù†ÙˆØ´ØªÙ… ğŸ˜…Ù‡Ù…ÙˆÙ† Ø§ÙˆÙ„ Ù…ÛŒØªÙˆÙ†Ø³ØªÙ† Ø¨Ú¯Ù† Ø¬Ù†Ø§Ø¨ Ù…ÙˆÙ‚Ø¹ÛŒØª Ù…Ú©Ø§Ù†ÛŒ Ø´Ù…Ø§ Ø¨Ø¯Ø±Ø¯ Ù…Ø§ Ù†Ù…ÛŒØ®ÙˆØ±Ù‡ØªØ³Ú©:### Task Breakdown#### Objective:The candidate must build a simple RESTful API for a blog application using ASP.NET Core. This task evaluates their ability to create a basic web service with CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations.#### Detailed Requirements:1. Create a New Blog Post: - HTTP Method: POST - Route: /api/posts - Request Body: JSON containing the required fields (e.g., title, content, author). - Validation: Ensure that title and content are not empty. - Response: Return the created post along with a success status code (e.g., 201 Created).2. Retrieve All Blog Posts: - HTTP Method: GET - Route: /api/posts - Response: Return a list of all blog posts in JSON format.3. Retrieve a Single Blog Post: - HTTP Method: GET - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Response: Return the specific blog post if it exists or an error status (e.g., 404 Not Found).4. Update a Blog Post: - HTTP Method: PUT - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Request Body: JSON with updated fields for the blog post. - Validation: Similar to creation, validate non-empty fields. - Response: Return the updated post or an appropriate error status if the post doesn't exist.5. Delete a Blog Post: - HTTP Method: DELETE - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Response: Return a success status for deletion or an error status if the post doesn't exist.#### Technical Choices:- ASP.NET Core: Use the latest version to leverage contemporary features and practices.- Entity Framework Core: Use for data access. An in-memory database can be used for simplicity during the test setup and execution.- Error Handling: Implement basic error handling to manage cases like invalid data, missing resources, etc.- Model Validation: Utilize ASP.NET Coreâ€™s built-in validation framework to ensure data integrity.#### Unit Testing:- Write at least two unit tests to verify the applicationâ€™s behavior. This could include tests for: - Successfully creating a blog post. - Fetching a non-existent blog post returns the appropriate error.#### Bonus Points:- Pagination: Implement pagination for the list of blog posts with query parameters like pageNumber and pageSize.- Logging: Introduce logging for critical operations to aid in monitoring and debugging. ASP.NET Core logging can be used to log to the console or a file.

CAN A DOMESTIC AGREEMENT BE ENFORCED?In the law of contract, There exist a presumption that social and domestic agreements are not enforceable, in other words they are not binding. The reason for this is that, it is presumed that there are no intentions to create legal relations when engaging in social and domestic agreements due to the nature of the agreements.This presumption is a rebuttable one. This means that there are instances where the court may infer an intention to create legal relations and enforce a domestic agreement.These instances may be regarded as the exceptions to the general presumption. These instances when proved or established, negates the presumption that social and domestic agreements are not binding.These instances are;When the parties within the domestic relationship were clearly not living in amity as at the time the agreement was made. This includes a situation where a couple are living apart as a result of a breakdown in the marriage. See the case of MERRITT V MERRITT.Again, a domestic agreement may be enforceable in situations were a party has made a great sacrifice in the process of making the agreement that it would be unfair and lead to great injustice if the agreement is not enforceable. In this instance, the great sacrifice represents consideration. See the case of PARKER V CLARK.Finally, a domestic agreement may be enforced by a court of law where evidence is adduced to show that parties to the contract  did intend to create legal relations in the terms of the agreement. This is because parties are free to agree to whatever they want to, so far it is within the ambit of the law.

This task evaluates their ability to create a basic web service with CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations.#### Detailed Requirements:1. Create a New Blog Post: - HTTP Method: POST - Route: /api/posts - Request Body: JSON containing the required fields (e.g., title, content, author). - Validation: Ensure that title and content are not empty. - Response: Return the created post along with a success status code (e.g., 201 Created).2. Retrieve All Blog Posts: - HTTP Method: GET - Route: /api/posts - Response: Return a list of all blog posts in JSON format.3. Retrieve a Single Blog Post: - HTTP Method: GET - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Response: Return the specific blog post if it exists or an error status (e.g., 404 Not Found).4. Update a Blog Post: - HTTP Method: PUT - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Request Body: JSON with updated fields for the blog post. - Validation: Similar to creation, validate non-empty fields. - Response: Return the updated post or an appropriate error status if the post doesn't exist.5. Delete a Blog Post: - HTTP Method: DELETE - Route: /api/posts/{id} - Response: Return a success status for deletion or an error status if the post doesn't exist.#### Technical Choices:- ASP.NET Core: Use the latest version to leverage contemporary features and practices.- Entity Framework Core: Use for data access. An in-memory database can be used for simplicity during the test setup and execution.- Error Handling: Implement basic error handling to manage cases like invalid data, missing resources, etc.- Model Validation: Utilize ASP.NET Coreâ€™s built-in validation framework to ensure data integrity.#### Unit Testing:- Write at least two unit tests to verify the applicationâ€™s behavior. This could include tests for: - Successfully creating a blog post. - Fetching a non-existent blog post returns the appropriate error.#### Bonus Points:- Pagination: Implement pagination for the list of blog posts with query parameters like pageNumber and pageSize.- Logging: Introduce logging for critical operations to aid in monitoring and debugging. ASP.NET Core logging can be used to log to the console or a file.
